FESEM and Fe EDX mapping images of FePc/SWCNT (i, m), FePc/SWCNT-f (j, n), FePc/hCNT (k, o) and FePc/hCNT-f (l, p). Fig. 2 Fe 2p (a), N 1s (b) and P 2p (c) XPS spectra of FePc, SWCNT, FePc/SWCNT, SWCNT-f, FePc/SWCNT-f, hCNT, FePc/hCNT, hCNT-f and FePc/hCNT-f samples. Fig. 3 Cyclic voltammograms (CVs) of Glassy Carbon (GC) electrodes modified with SWCNT, SWCNT-f, FePc/SWCNT and FePc/SWCNT-f (a) and hCNT, hCNT-f, FePc/hCNT and FePc/hCNT-f (b) from 0.0 V to 1.0 V in N2-saturated (solid lines) and O2-saturated (dashed lines) 0.1 M KOH solution at 50 mV s−1. Fig. 4 ORR polarization curves (a), number of electrons transferred (n) per oxygen molecule (b), Tafel plots (c) and half-wave potentials (E 1/2) (d) derived from the RRDE tests during the ORR for Pt/C, SWCNT, SWCNT-f, FePc/SWCNT, FePc/SWCNT-f, hCNT, hCNT-f, FePc/hCNT and FePc/hCNT-f catalysts in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH solution at an electrode rotation rate of 1600 r/min and a scan rate of 5 mV s−1. Fig. 5 ORR redox mechanism on FeN4 macrocyclic systems in aqueous alkaline medium via two-electron (purple route) and four-electron (green route) (adapted from [85]). Fig. 6 LSV durability test of FePc/hCNT and FePc/hCNT-f before and after 500 cycles in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH solution at 50 mV s−1 and a rotation rate of 1600 r/min (a) and chronoamperometric curves (Normalized j vs. time) of FePc/hCNT, FePc/hCNT-f and Pt/C electrode with a given potential of 0.65 V in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH electrolyte with a rotation rate of 1600 r/min (T = 25 °C) (b). Fig. 7 Optimized molecular structures of FePc on CNT (a and b) and CNT-f (c and d). H is white, C is grey, N is blue, O is red, P is yellow and Fe is orange. Fig. 8 Free energy diagram of FePc (a) and FePc/2APPA (b) for the ORR at 1.23 V (blue lines), 0.65 V (orange lines) and 0 V (purple lines). Diagram comparison of both systems at 1.23 V (c). Graphical abstract FePc molecules supported on CNTs electrochemically modified with N and P-species promote axial coordination that enhances catalytic activity and stability towards ORR. Iron(II) phthalocyanines (FePc) supported on functionalized nanostructured carbon materials have been studied as electrocatalysts for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) in an alkaline medium. Herein, two types of carbon nanotubes (CNTs) have been explored as support, Single-Walled Carbon Nanotubes and Herringbone Carbon Nanotubes (SWCNTs and hCNTs, respectively), both electrochemically modified with ortho- aminophenylphosphonic acid (2APPA), which provides phosphate axial coordinating ligands for the immobilization of FePc molecules. All the catalysts were prepared via a facile incipient wetness impregnation method. Comprehensive experimental analysis together with density functional theory (DFT) calculations has demonstrated both the importance of the five-coordinated Fe macrocycles that favor the interaction between the FePc and the carbon support, as well as the effect of the CNT structure in the ORR. FePc axial coordination provides a better dispersion, leading to higher stability and a favorable electron redistribution that also tunes the ORR performance by lowering the stability of the reaction intermediates. Interestingly, such improvement occurs with a very low content of metal (∼1 wt% Fe), which is especially remarkable when hCNT support is employed. This work provides a novel strategy for the development of Fe-containing complexes as precious metal-free catalysts towards the ORR. Keywords Carbon nanotubes Iron phthalocyanine Oxygen reduction Electrocatalysis Axial ligand 1 Introduction Technological breakthroughs and their constant innovation have meant a major revolution in people’s lives. Consequently, the current growth in global energy demand and the increase in greenhouse gas emissions to the environment, has given way to intensive research for the implementation of efficient, clean and sustainable energy alternatives, together with the reduction of fossil fuel dependence [1]. In this context, electrochemical energy generation and storage devices have become vitally important because of their high efficiency and low generation of pollutants [2]. The oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is a key step in many renewable and energy-saving technologies, such as fuel cells or metal-air batteries [3–5]. Interestingly, the electrochemical reduction of O2 is also important in the synthesis of hydrogen peroxide and electrochemical sensors [6]. However, the sluggish nature of ORR kinetics is the major restriction to implementing these technologies for commercial applications, since the overall reaction performance is affected by the large overpotential, multiple intermediates, structural reorganization and electron transfer steps [7]. So far, Pt nanoparticles and Pt-containing electrodes are known as the most efficient state-of-the-art electrocatalysts for ORR [8,9], but their scarcity, high cost and poisoning deactivation limit their large-scale applications [10–12]. To address these drawbacks, intensive research efforts are imperative to design more efficient, durable and cheaper alternatives to the commercially available electrocatalysts. In the last years, different perspectives have been explored, not only for the decrease of Pt content on the catalysts [13], but also for the development of non-precious metal catalysts, such as metal-free carbon materials [14] and transition metal (Fe/Co/Ni/Cu/Mo)-based materials (and their oxides) [15,16]. Particularly, the use of metal-N4 coordination compounds (MN4), such as metal porphyrins and phthalocyanines, have been extensively investigated since the 1960s, when Jasinski et al. [17] first noticed their highly promising potential as electrocatalyst in the oxygen electrochemical reduction in fuel cells and metal-air batteries. Their centrosymmetric conjugated structure together with the richness of their redox chemistry provides their unique properties and wide applicability in many fields other than electrocatalysis, such as supercapacitors [18] or sensors [19]. Moreover, MN4 macrocycles aroused much attention because of their low price, excellent thermal and chemical stabilities and tailorable catalytic activity [20]. Concerning the ORR, diverse factors are important for describing the activity of MN4 electrocatalysts, including the d electrons of the metal, the binding energy to dioxygen (donor–acceptor intermolecular interaction of N4-M-O2) or reacting molecule and intermediates, the catalytic site density and accessibility towards the active sites and the formal M(n)+/M(n−1)+ redox potential of the catalysts, among others [21,22]. Interestingly, many of these parameters are strongly influenced by the central metal ion and the environment of the MN4 complex. Among all the metallic complexes, numerous contributions have highlighted the particular use of iron (II) phthalocyanines (FePc) supported by a wide variety of nanostructured carbon materials [16,23] as extraordinary candidates in terms of high ORR activity, resistance to CO deactivation and tolerance towards methanol crossover [21,23,24]. The catalytic behaviour of FePc is largely governed by the central FeII atom in Fe-Nx configuration as the active sites for ORR, which is mainly due to the partially filled d orbitals in Fe complexes [21,25,26]. However, further progress in the long-term durability and selectivity is still required, since Fe-N-C catalysts are known to suffer from degradation in fuel cell conditions [24,26]. Furthermore, it is essential to consider the large influence of the nature of the support on the electrocatalytic performance [20,23], sometimes even higher than the metal identity of these macrocycles or their functionalization/substitution. Therefore, a key factor is to find the most convenient support that favors the correct distribution of FePc molecules with sufficiently strong interaction, in order to facilitate the accessibility of oxygen to the active sites and the subsequent electron transfer through the inner-sphere mechanism during the electrochemical reduction of O2 [20,21,27]. Particularly, carbon nanotubes (CNTs) have been placed into the focus of recent studies for the immobilization of catalysts because of their extraordinary fast electron delivery to the ORR active sites, together with a high specific surface area, mechanical strength and chemical and electrochemical stabilities [28]. Different structures of CNTs have been studied as supports [22,27,29], since it has been proven that molecular catalysts can be suitably physisorbed and homogeneously distributed on the surface of typical Single-Walled and Multi-Walled CNTs. However, from our understanding, other structures such as Herringbone-type CNTs have not been studied yet for this purpose, in spite of the fact that this structure can be beneficial due to their large number of highly reactive sites (e.g., defects, edges, etc.), what may increase the interaction with FePc molecules. In this sense, both the intrinsic catalytic activity, selectivity and long-term stability of FePc can be positively modulated by a strong interaction to the carbon support. Owing to their high chemical versatility, several approaches have been attempted to boost the performance of these macrocyclic complexes for the ORR, including the synthesis of different catalyst configurations and the chemical modification of both the carbon support and the iron complexes [30] (FePc nanoparticles [31], metal–organic frameworks based on phthalocyanines or polymerization of molecular catalysts [3], etc.). Particularly, the pyrolysis of FePc-based catalysts has been extensively employed for stabilizing Fe-N/C structures and enhancing the ORR activity [32]. Nevertheless, changes in chemical and electronic structures around the metal are often unpredictable during such thermal treatments, making identification and controlled design of the active center difficult. Indeed, some authors proposed that unheated FePc adsorbed on carbon materials show better activity but worse stability than pyrolyzed catalysts [33]. One potential alternative consists of the peripheral and non-peripheral FePc substitution with targeted functional groups or atoms. Here, the presence of peripheral electron-withdrawing substituents in FePc molecules, such as fluorinated [34], chlorinated [35] and cyano [36] phthalocyanines, leads to an optimal electronic coupling between the oxygen reduction and the Fe3+/Fe2+ redox potential, thus favoring the ORR process. On the other hand, more promising efforts result from the axially covalent coordination of non-modified FePc with the carbon supports, including different axial ligands, such as pyridine [35,37], imidazole [38] and oxygen-containing groups [39,40]. Interestingly, such strategies not only serve as an “anchor” toward enhanced stability and conductivity, but also prevent the FePc aggregation and deformation [39]. Furthermore, the reactivity of the metal center can be fine-tuned through the reorganization of the electronic density and geometric structure of the symmetric tetracoordinated planar FeN4 center in phthalocyanines [41]. In general, the incorporation of suitable electron-donating functional groups into carbon materials has successfully demonstrated the five-coordination with FePc [40], thus regulating the stability and catalytic performance of the material. Within the wide variety of possible ligands, phosphate groups are extensively known for their chemical versatility and efficient coordination of divalent transition metals [42,43]. However, no studies have been found to date for axial coordination of FePc with phosphate ligands. Following the last approach, one promising strategy consists of the incorporation of coordination sites to anchor metals by the functional polymer wrapping on the CNTs [28]. Polyaniline (PANI) is one of the most renowned conducting polymers because of its low-cost, conductivity, stability and chemical versatility [44], which can be polymerized in a controlled manner by electrochemical methods, without significantly damaging the structure of the CNTs. Interestingly, PANI can be widely substituted with different functional groups in its structure (sulfonic, phosphonic, etc.) [45,46], which allows to modulate its intrinsic properties according to the desired application. Here, the incorporation of suitable axial ligands in PANI structure, such as phosphate groups, can be interesting to coordinate iron atoms in FePc molecules. In this sense, multiple approaches have been studied for years for the preparation of metal transition-based catalysts supported onto functionalized or non-functionalized CNTs [47–49]. Nonetheless, most of these works make use of chemical or thermal procedures. Here, electrochemical techniques arise as a well-suited tool for the tailorable design of modified CNTs with more precise control and selectivity over the composition and functional groups, by carefully controlling the electrochemical conditions. In addition, electrochemical techniques are highlighted for being cost-efficient also from the environmental point of view, usually working at near room temperature and atmospheric pressure with small volumes and low amounts of reagents [50–52]. Therefore, the combination of electrochemical functionalization together with the facile and widely used incipient wetness impregnation method could be an interesting strategy to achieve higher control over the final properties and catalytic performance towards the ORR. In this work, we present the synthesis of composite materials based on non-pyrolyzed iron phthalocyanine (FePc) immobilized on modified CNTs with a low content of metal (∼1 wt% Fe). Two different structures of CNTs are studied as support, both the Single-Walled Carbon Nanotubes (SWCNTs) and Herringbone Carbon Nanotubes (hCNTs). Interestingly, phosphate species electrochemically incorporated on CNTs at the experimental conditions used [53] have been employed as suitable axial ligands for iron macrocycles, which leads to improved activity, stability and selectivity towards the ORR in an alkaline medium, in which the electrocatalytic performance is close to that of the commercial Pt/C catalyst. In order to better elucidate the origin of the ORR performance, density functional theory (DFT) calculations have also been implemented. 2 Experimental 2.1 Reagents and material preparation Single-Walled/Double-Walled Carbon Nanotubes (SW/DWCNTs) with 99% of purity (outer diameter: 1–4 nm, length: 3–30 mm) and a specific surface area, obtained by nitrogen isotherm at 77 K using the Brunauer Emmett and Teller (BET) method, of 587 m2 g−1 were supplied by Cheap Tubes Inc. (Brattleboro, Vt, USA). SW/DWCNTs consist of an approximately 50/50 mix of Single-Walled and Double-Walled Carbon Nanotubes, in which the possible content of Multi-Walled Carbon Nanotubes (MWCNTs) is <2%. From now on, they will be named SWCNTs. As-received SWCNTs (200 mg) were transferred into a round bottom flask along with 100 mL of acid solution (HNO3:HCl = 3:5, molar ratio) in an aqueous medium at 70 °C for 12 h under reflux conditions. The purified SWCNTs were filtered and washed extensively with deionized water until reaching a pH of 7. Finally, they were dried in an oven at 120 °C in the air overnight. Herringbone Carbon Nanotubes (hCNTs) were purchased from Tokyo Chemical Industry with 95% of purity (outer diameter: 10–20 nm, length: 5–15 mm) and a specific surface area of 123 m2 g−1 [54]. Because the hCNTs do not present any surface metal content, they were used without further purification. The ortho- aminophenylphosphonic acid (2APPA, ≥95%) was supplied by Chem Space (Riga, Lithuania). Iron(II) phthalocyanine (FePc, 90%) as well as platinum supported on a graphitized carbon material (20 wt% Pt) were used as received from Sigma-Aldrich (named Pt/C). Fumion® FAA-3 was used as an anion exchange material (counter ion bromide) and was supplied by Fumatech BWT GmbH (Bietigheim-Bissingen, Germany). Isopropanol (C3H8O, 99.5%), sulphuric acid (H2SO4, 98%) and potassium hydroxide (KOH, 85%) were purchased from VWR Chemicals. N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF), extra pure, employed as a dispersant of CNTs, was provided by Scharlau. Hydrochloric acid (HCl, 37%) and nitric acid (HNO3, 65%) used as a purifying agent of SWCNTs, were purchased from PanReac AppliChem (ITW Reagents). All aqueous solutions were prepared with ultrapure water (18.2 MΩ·cm, Millipore® Milli-Q® water). Nitrogen gas (N2, 99.999%), oxygen gas (O2, 99.995%) and (H2, 99.999%) were supplied by Carburos Metálicos. 2.2 Electrochemical modification of CNTs with 2APPA The procedure for the electrochemical functionalization of CNTs with 2APPA has been scaled-up from our previous work [53]. In this study, a 1 mg mL−1 dispersion of each type of CNTs in DMF, previously prepared by ultrasonication, was deposited in a rectangular glassy carbon electrode (GC, (40 × 9 mm2) × 2 sides) by drop-casting method leading to a GC electrode loading of 0.27 mg cm−2. The electrochemical set-up consists of a BioLogic SP300 Potentiostat-Galvanostat controlled by a computer and a standard three-electrode cell, where the GC modified with the CNTs was used as a working electrode (WE), a graphite rod as the counter electrode (CE) and a Ag/AgCl/Cl−(sat) electrode connected with the electrolyte in a Luggin capillary as the reference electrode (RE). Nevertheless, all the potentials in this work were converted to the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). Further information related to the calibration of the reference electrode can be found in Supplementary material (Fig. S1). The electrochemical modification of CNTs was carried out by cyclic voltammetry (CV) during 10 cycles at 10 mV s−1, in an aqueous electrolyte of 0.5 M H2SO4 containing 5 mM 2APPA, previously deoxygenated by bubbling N2, and at room temperature. Furthermore, the optimal upper potential limit conditions were employed to achieve the highest incorporation of N and P species on the CNTs, that is, at 1.2 V and 1.4 V with SWCNTs and hCNTs, respectively, resulting in SWCNT-f and hCNT-f samples, respectively. After electrochemical modification, the WE was repeatedly washed with ultrapure water to remove the remaining electrolyte. Fig. S2(a and b) shows the cyclic voltammograms of the electrochemical functionalization of SWCNTs and hCNTs in which different redox processes appear during cycling and are related to electroactive functionalities incorporated onto the CNTs. Similar electrochemical behaviour is observed according to our previous work, thus revealing the development of species of the same nature and confirming the correct scaling-up of the process. Moreover, Fig. S2(c) displays the thermogravimetric profiles for CNTs before and after their electrochemical functionalization with 2APPA (generally denoted as CNT and CNT-f, respectively), which confirm again the incorporation of 2APPA-related species. 2.3 Decorating metal species on N and P-doped CNTs Iron phthalocyanines were supported onto the CNTs by using the incipient wetness impregnation method. For that purpose, an appropriate amount of iron complexes dissolved by ultrasonication in DMF (0.1 mg mL−1) was mixed with the CNTs (previously dried under vacuum) to obtain a nominal metal loading of 1 wt%. Afterward, the solvent was evaporated by infrared light at 250 W (Philips, IR 250 RH IR2, 230–250 V, Korea) for about 3 h, resulting in FePc/SWCNT and FePc/hCNT samples. The same procedure was done onto CNT-f materials, thus resulting in FePc/SWCNT-f and FePc/hCNT-f samples. 2.4 Physico-chemical and morphological characterization FTIR spectra were measured in a Nicolet 5700 spectrometer (Thermo Electron Corporation, Waltham, Massachusetts, USA) equipped with a Mercury-Cadmium Telluride (MCT) detector cooled with liquid nitrogen and at 4 cm−1 resolution. All the samples were prepared in KBr pellets by applying a constant force of 5 tons for 5 min. The FTIR spectra were expressed as transmittance. The surface chemical analysis of all FePc/CNT hybrid materials was performed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) with a VG-Microtech Multilab 3000 spectrometer equipped with a semispherical electron analyzer with 9 channeltrons (passing energy of 2–200 eV) and an X-ray source with Al radiation (Kα 1253.6 eV). The deconvolutions of the Fe 2p, P 2p and N 1s peaks were done by minimum squares fitting using Gaussian-Lorentzian curves, while the Shirley method was used for background determination. The P 2p spectra were analyzed considering the spin–orbit splitting into P 2p3/2 and P 2p1/2 with a 2:1 peak area ratio and 0.87 eV splitting. Raman spectroscopy is a powerful tool that provides information about the structural changes in the of CNTs after decorating with FePc. Raman spectra were collected by a Jasco NRS-5100 spectrometer, using a 532 nm solid-state laser (green) at 3.9 mW, a 20x objective (MPLFLN) and a focal distance of 300 mm. Calibration of the spectrometer must be performed before the analysis, with a Si slice (521 ± 2 cm−1) in order to check the response peak at 520 cm−1 and to eliminate possible interferences by the effect of fluorescence. Each spectrum was collected after 120 s. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on DSC-TGA equipment (simultaneous TGA/DSC SDT Q600, TA Instruments, New Castle, Delaware, USA). Around 5 mg of the dried sample was put in the thermobalance. The thermobalance was purged for 45 min under the He flow rate of 100 mL min−1 and then heated up to 900 °C (heating rate 10 °C min−1). Microstructural and morphological characterization of the different materials was performed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL JEM-2010 model, INCA Energy TEM 100 model microscope with an electron beam of 200 keV, equipped with a GATAN acquisition camera, Croissy, France), and field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, ZEISS microscope, Merlin VP Compact model equipped with an EDX microanalysis system BRUKER Quantax 400 model). In addition, scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was also performed by using the Hitachi S-3000 N microscope (Chiyoda, Japan). 2.5 Electrochemical measurements Electrochemical characterization of FePc-containing composites and the study of the electrocatalytic activity towards the ORR were performed in a three-electrode cell in 0.1 M KOH electrolyte at 25 °C and using an Autolab PGSTAT302 with a dual-mode biopotentiostat module (Metrohm, Netherlands). A rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE, Pine Research Instruments, USA) is equipped with a glassy carbon disk (5.61 mm diameter, 0.25 cm2) and a Pt ring (0.19 cm2) as working electrodes. Moreover, a graphite bar (supplied by Mersen Ibérica) and a home-made reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) immersed in the same electrolyte in a Luggin capillary were used as a counter and reference electrode, respectively. Further information related to the calibration of the reference electrode can be found in Supplementary material (Fig. S1). The catalysts ink containing FePc/CNT and FePc/CNT-f samples was prepared by ultrasonically merging a suspension of 1 mg mL−1 of each composite (20 vol% isopropanol, 80 vol% water and 0.02 vol% Fumion®) and the amount of catalyst loading on the disk electrode was optimized in 0.48 mg cm−2. Electrochemical behaviour in 0.1 M KOH N2-saturated solution was first studied by cyclic voltammetry (CV) in a potential range from 0.0 V to 1.0 V at 50 mV s−1. Then, the electrocatalytic performance of the materials towards the ORR was studied in 0.1 M KOH O2-saturated electrolyte by linear sweep voltammetry (LSV), which consists of cycling between 1.0 V and 0.0 V at a scan rate of 5 mV s−1. Kinetic parameters were obtained at six different rotation rates between 400 and 2025 r/min. In addition, 20 wt% Pt/C (Sigma-Aldrich) was also analyzed for comparison purposes. The potential of the Pt ring electrode was kept constant at 1.5 V during all measurements to ensure that all the hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) reaching the Pt ring was oxidized. Then, the electron transfer number (n) was determined as follows: n = (4 I disk)/(I disk + I ring/N), where I disk and I ring are the currents measured at the disk and ring electrode, respectively, and N is the collection efficiency of the ring electrode that has been experimentally determined to be 0.37. The Tafel slopes were acquired from LSV experiments by plotting the potential vs logarithm of the current (log j k) at low overpotentials (reaction under kinetic control). Finally, long-term durability tests were carried out for FePc/hCNT and FePc/hCNT-f at the same working conditions by cycling between 1.0 V and 0 V for 500 cycles and a rotation rate of 1600 r/min at 50 mV s−1. An additional stability test was performed by chronoamperometric measurements in which the working electrode potential was kept at 0.65 V in 0.1 M KOH O2-saturated electrolyte and a rotation rate of 1600 r/min for 2 h. After 2 h, a solution of 1 M CH3OH was added to the working electrolyte and the current was recorded for an additional 1 h. 2.6 Density functional theory calculations (DFT) Density Functional Theory calculations were performed in the Gaussian 09 software package [55] at B3LYP/6-31G(d) level [56–58]. Dispersive forces were considered and computed by using Grimme D3 scheme method and including the Becke-Johnson damping function (D3-BJ) to prevent interatomic repulsive contributions at short distances [59,60]. Restricted and unrestricted solutions were considered for closed and open-shell systems, respectively. In addition, the effect of the aqueous environment of the electrocatalytic experiment has been taken into account using the self-consistent reaction field (SCRF) solvation models with the continuous polarized model (PCM) [61] including the dielectric constant of water, thus reflecting the presence of the solvent. The changes in energies were calculated as the energy differences between the optimized structures of the final adduct and individual fragments energy and the energies are reported in kJ mol−1 (1 Hartree = 2625.5 kJ mol−1). The model structure used for FePc consists of a macrocycle with four pyrrole units with four carbons attached in the ring linked together by N bridges, and an iron metal atom coordinated with the pyrrole nitrogen atoms in the center of the ring. The carbon nanotube (CNT) consists of an armchair ended (5,5)-SWCNT of 160 atoms and a diameter of 0.7 nm. This model has been used to reduce computational costs, considering that SWCNTs typically have a diameter between 1 and 2 nm. Moreover, the functionalized carbon nanotube (CNT-f) was represented using the above structure together with a wall grafted ortho-aminophenylphosphate acid molecule. The free energy diagrams of the ORR are represented as the free energy of formation of each of the reaction intermediates and determined following the computational hydrogen electrode model potential [62], as described in detail in other works [63]. It should be noted that Pourbaix diagrams were previously obtained in order to know the most stable species from which the ORR catalytic cycle begins, where the most stable surface is plotted as a function of the potential (referred to the standard hydrogen electrode, U SHE) and the pH. The stability of the species was computed considering the system in equilibrium with protons and liquid water at 25 °C [64]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physico-chemical and morphological characterization of FePc/CNT and FePc/CNT-f composites FePc/CNTs composites were synthesized via the incipient wetness impregnation method on previously electrochemically functionalized CNTs with N and P-containing species (see Section 2.2 and 2.3 for detailed procedure), as schematically illustrated in Scheme 1 . The same procedure has been carried out on non-functionalized CNTs for comparison purposes. The morphology of unmodified and functionalized SWCNTs and hCNTs, together with their composites with FePc complexes was characterized by TEM and FESEM. On the one hand, as shown in Fig. 1 (a), SWCNTs display the typical tubular structure, with some defects or amorphous carbon residues on the walls after being slightly oxidized during the purification treatment with HNO3:HCl (3:5), which is confirmed by comparing XPS full survey spectra and TEM images before and after the acid treatment (Fig. S3). On the other hand, hCNTs in Fig. 1(c) are known to present conical graphite sheets stacked with highly reactive sites (such as edges and defects). Details of the surface morphology of both types of CNTs can be found in Fig. S4. Here, SEM images show a smoother surface for SWCNTs with smaller-sized tubes (Fig. S4a) compared to hCNTs (Fig. S4b). TEM images in Fig. S4(c and d) also confirm structural and morphological differences, in which the rougher surface of hCNTs could be related to the large presence of edges and defects (marked as white arrows in Fig. S4d), as mentioned above. After the electrochemical functionalization in the presence of 2APPA, an oligomeric coating envelops the surface of both CNTs with no apparent damage to their structure (Fig. 1b and d). It should be noted that SWCNT-f in Fig. 1(b) tends to aggregate in bunches of several CNTs, as detailed in our previous work [53]. In addition, Fig. S5 shows the area-scanning EDX mapping images of SWCNT-f and hCNT-f, in which N and P atoms are uniformly distributed on the CNTs, verifying the successful functionalization with 2APPA-related species. Different degrees of FePc aggregation can be distinguished with the different carbon supports (Fig. 1e-h), where SWCNTs induce a more uniform distribution than hCNTs through FePc adsorption on CNT walls via π-π stacking interaction [31] (Fig. 1e and f). In contrast, hCNTs reveal more heterogeneous FePc aggregation on the carbon surface, related to the presence of darker areas (marked with white arrows in Fig. 1g and h), probably at the most reactive sites. The structure and elemental distribution of FePc on the different supports were also analyzed by element mapping. As shown in Fig. 1(i-p), all the materials present a good distribution of iron phthalocyanines (Fe species are shown as red dots in Fig. 1(i-l) and as black dots in Fig. 1(m-p) for clearer visualization), despite noticing by TEM that hCNTs have more tendency to their agglomeration than SWCNTs. Remarkably, the presence of 2APPA-related species seems to effectively prevent the formation of FePc clusters, probably due to strong interactions of Fe species to functional groups incorporated on the support. Raman results in Fig. S6 show two main peaks located at around 1340 cm−1 and 1570–1590 cm−1 and assigned to the well-known D and G bands, respectively [65,66]. Considerable differences can be observed in the relative intensity ratio (I D/I G) of both carbon supports, which is used as an indication of the inherent disorder of carbon materials and/or an estimated degree of functionalization [67]. In this sense, a higher I D/I G value is seen in hCNTs (0.74) than SWCNTs (0.26), suggesting that more defect sites (highly reactive) are available for anchoring FePc molecules [38]. For SWCNTs (Fig. S6a), the I D/I G ratio does not show substantial changes when FePc species are supported (FePc/SWCNT) (0.24), since they are physically adsorbed on SWCNTs via π-π interactions. No significant displacements of the G band are observed (inset in Fig. S6a). On the contrary, an increase in the I D/I G value can be observed in FePc/hCNT composite (0.90) as compared to that of the unmodified hCNTs (0.74) (Fig. S6b), thus confirming the formation of stacking defects after the incorporation of FePc molecules. On the other hand, higher I D/I G ratio is shown for hCNT-f sample (0.91) compared to hCNT (0.74), indicating that more stacking defects have also been created after the covalent grafting of functionalities on the surface of the hCNTs, as expected from their numerous highly reactive sites. No significant differences in the I D/I G ratio are appreciated before and after supporting FePc on SWCNT-f or hCNT-f supports, which clearly indicates that interactions of such macrocycles occur preferentially through covalently attached functional moieties. In addition, an upward shift of the G band is observed in all hCNT-based compounds due to interactions with either FePc or 2APPA-species [68] (inset in Fig. S6b), together with a pronounced shoulder at around 1624 cm−1, especially for FePc/hCNT sample. This shoulder could be related to a small contribution of unsupported FePc bands, which disappear in FePc/hCNT-f due to their better dispersion. Actually, the spectrum of FePc/hCNT shows some peaks between 1300 cm−1 and 1600 cm−1 that could be associated with agglomerated FePc molecules (as seen for FePcexp in Fig. S6c), while in FePc/hCNT-f these peaks are less appreciated. It should be mentioned that the Raman spectrum of unsupported FePc (FePcexp) is in good agreement with that reported in the literature [69]. However, some differences can be distinguished compared to the calculated Raman spectrum for an isolated FePc molecule (FePccomp). In this sense, some of the strongest peaks for FePccomp at 1136, 1394 and 1474 cm−1 related to in-plane bending vibrations [70] seem to be hindered by stacking effects. Therefore, it can be confirmed that the peaks discerned for FePc/hCNT catalyst are related to stacked FePc molecules, in agreement with TEM observations (Fig. 1) where higher agglomeration was observed for this sample. These peaks are not noticed for SWCNT-based catalysts, indicating the better distribution of FePc molecules on this carbon support [23]. The surface chemical composition was further investigated by XPS. Table 1 reports the atomic percentages (and mass percentages of metallic content) of the different composites, as well as unmodified CNTs and unsupported FePc for comparison purposes. An increase in N and P can be found in SWCNT-f and hCNT-f samples, which confirms the successful incorporation of functionalities after electrochemical treatments in the presence of 2APPA. Regarding the oxygen content, it can be related to that present in CNTs, as well as that obtained during the electrooxidation in oxidative conditions, together with that of APPA functionalization and from impurities of FePc molecules. As XPS results reflect, CNTs do not present Fe or other metal, thus confirming that they have been removed correctly after purification. Therefore, the presence of Fe-containing species corroborates the incorporation of FePc molecules on CNTs, where the mass percentage obtained (in parentheses in Table 1) is close to the nominal value (1 wt% Fe). It can be noted that the use of hCNTs as support leads to a slightly higher concentration of FePc species on the surface, especially when modifying them with N and P species, compared to SWCNTs. Additionally, the metal content determined by EDX analysis is shown so as to get information on the distribution of FePc species in the bulk of the material. Fig. S7 shows the EDX spectra of FePc-containing catalysts. In this sense, the values obtained by XPS for SWCNT-related samples match perfectly with those of EDX, which indicates that the distribution of FePc is homogeneous throughout the material. Nonetheless, FePc species seem to be more heterogeneously distributed on the surface of either modified or unmodified hCNTs, as suggested in TEM and FESEM-EDX analysis. The atomic ratio of FePc/CNTs between the N 1s and Fe 2p peaks is somewhat higher than the theoretical 8:1 ratio of FePc molecules, which confirms the incorporation of most these types of structure without apparent damage. The values slightly higher than the theoretical one could be related to impurities from the reagents since the pure FePc gives also a value higher than 8. In order to get a better understanding of the chemical nature of iron-based catalysts, deconvoluted Fe 2p, N 1s and P 2p core-level spectra are displayed in Fig. 2 . Despite the complex multiple structure, Fe 2p scan in Fig. 2(a) can be divided into seven different peaks corresponding to 2p3/2 FeII (709.2 eV), 2p3/2 FeIII (711.2 eV), 2p3/2 Fe-O (714.3 eV), FeIII satellite (718.3 eV), 2p1/2 FeII (722.5 eV), 2p1/2 FeIII (724.7 eV) and 2p1/2 Fe-O (727.5 eV) states [39]. Substantial changes in the oxidation states are clearly observed when FePc molecules are supported, where a clear shift towards more positive binding energies (∼2.3 eV) can be explained by the interactions with the carbon support via π-stacking or interactions between FePc and surface functionalities present in CNTs [39], that stabilize the FeIII species. This displacement is slightly lower with SWCNTs supports (∼2.1 eV), since hCNTs show more reactive points, which is consistent with Raman results. Interestingly, interactions are more strongly appreciated on functionalized CNTs (∼3.2 eV), indicating a higher decrease in the electron density in FePc macrocycles due to its axial coordination with functionalities that stabilize the FeIII oxidation state, which is consistent with previous investigations [35,37]. To the best of our knowledge, such a remarkable shift had not been observed before in any study related to the coordination of FePc molecules with axial ligands on carbon supports. Moreover, the content of Fe-O shows an appreciable growth (Table 1), especially in the presence of 2APPA-related oligomers (CNT-f), which is in favor of the increase of axial interactions that prevent the FePc aggregation. It should be noted that the percentages of Fe-O species for FePc/CNT and FePc/CNT-f catalysts in Table 1 should subtract the value of 6.5% of Fe-O species related to the initial state of FePc molecules, in order to obtain the total contribution of Fe-O interaction after supporting FePc molecules. These results are in accordance with other works, where it was found that the presence of surface oxygen groups induces the enhancement of the interaction and distribution of FePc molecules on carbon-based supports [39,40]. This effect could also be linked to the better stability of the FePc/SWCNT-f and FePc/hCNT-f dispersions in DMF solution during the wet impregnation process (Fig. S8), as well as in the more uniform distribution of FePc molecules on SWCNT-f and hCNT-f with respect to unmodified supports (Fig. 1). The fitting of the N 1s XPS spectra in Fig. 2(b) only shows one main peak for unsupported FePc at 398.9 eV (-N-Fefree) includes the two different chemical environments surrounding the N atoms in FePc molecules, whose contributions are very close to each other. The presence of smaller contributions at higher binding energies is mainly related to impurities in the initial material [29]. When FePc are supported on carbon-based materials, another contribution can be fitted at 400.3–400.5 eV (-N-Fe-) attributed to CN bonds in FePc structure [68,71] interacting with the carbon support. A slightly upward displacement (∼0.3 eV) of this peak for FePc/hCNT and FePc/hCNT-f samples (compared to FePc/SWCNT and FePc/SWCNT-f samples) could suggest a higher interaction with this sort of carbon nanotubes due to the higher density of reactive points such as edges and defects, also in agreement with the previous Raman results (Fig. S6). An additional N peak appears at 399.9 eV for the neutral amine or amide-type nitrogen (–NH-2APPA) coming from the 2APPA-related species [72,73], together with the third contribution at higher binding energies (401.6 eV) connected with oxidized and positively charged N sites (N+) [74]. Interestingly, the functionalization of CNTs results in a lower contribution of free phthalocyanines (-N-Fefree), thus increasing the FePc molecules interacting with the support (higher area ratio of the (-N-Fe-) and (-N-Fefree) contribution, A int/A free in Fig. 2b). Only one asymmetric doublet appears in the P 2p spectra in Fig. 2(c) for SWCNT-f and hCNT-f supports at 133.5 eV, which lies in the range of P-O species and possibly ascribed to phosphate or phosphoric groups (R–O–P(OH)2) generated during the electrochemical modification at oxidative environments [75]. Interestingly, the downward shift in the binding energies by ∼0.3 eV after the impregnation of FePc molecules could be related to possible axial coordination of the central Fe atom with phosphate ligands (P-O-Fe). Consistent with this discussion, a displacement towards the same direction is also observed in the O 1s spectra in Fig. S9. It is important to mention that multiple investigations have demonstrated covalent interactions between FePc molecules and oxygen groups present on carbon supports [39,40]. Particularly, it has been proven that the oxygen incorporated after the electrochemical treatments is mainly associated with phosphate groups and not with the support oxidation, since the O/P ratios shown in Table 1 are quite close to the theoretical value of 4. Therefore, it has been considered that the differences in the interactions of FePc with unmodified and functionalized supports are tightly associated with the axial attachment of such macrocycle complexes to phosphate groups. Likewise, the FTIR spectra in Fig. S10 reveal the characteristic framework of FePc at around 730–732 cm−1 for all FePc-containing samples, which could be related to Fe-N stretching [76] or interactions of peripheral-ring hydrogen atoms with carbon atoms (C–H non-planar deformation) [31]. Interestingly, this contribution is clearly more intense on functionalized CNTs, together with an additional band at around 720–722 cm−1. It should be noted that pure FePc presents a band at 721 cm−1 related to the skeleton of metal phthalocyanine rings [77]. Therefore, the presence of such contribution should be derived from axial interactions with FePc molecules that keep the peripheral-ring away from the possible structural distortion that occurs near the nanotubes. Other C-, N- and P-related bands at 980–992 cm−1, 1031–1036 cm−1, 1211–1215 cm−1, 1382–1385 cm−1 and 1551–1568 cm−1 can be also distinguished [78,79]. The above experimental results reveal that the presence of functional moieties such as amine-type nitrogen and, especially, phosphate groups electrochemically incorporated on carbon supports is conductive to strengthening the interactions between FePc and both types of CNTs. This suggests an effective five-coordination system by binding axial phosphate ligands together with the influence of N functionalities, which could be helpful to boost the ORR performance. 3.2 Electrochemical evaluation Fig. 3 shows the electrochemical behavior of all materials recorded by cyclic voltammetry (CV) and measured in N2-saturated (solid lines) and O2-saturated (dashed lines) 0.1 M KOH aqueous solutions. Regarding the characterization in an inert atmosphere (solid lines in Fig. 3), SWCNT and hCNT correspond to both unmodified carbon nanotubes, in which pure capacitive response is clearly observed. Nonetheless, the slight presence of broad redox processes at 0.5–0.6 V (1/1′ in Fig. 3 for oxidation/reduction peak, respectively) could be related to surface oxygen species [80], as revealed by the XPS analysis in Table 1. In addition, one redox couple at around 0.7–0.8 V (2/2′) is observed in functionalized CNTs (SWCNT-f and hCNT-f), together with other minor processes, associated with incorporated electroactive polymeric N and P functionalities [53]. Typically, two well-defined redox pairs (at around 0.3 V (3/3′) and 0.8 V (4/4′), respectively) originated from the FePc molecules, which are closely related to the electrocatalytic activity of the materials. CVs of four FePc-containing electrodes (FePc/SWCNT, FePc/SWCNT-f, FePc/hCNT and FePc/hCNT-f samples) present redox processes in the potentials expected for the FeII/FeI and FeIII/FeII transitions. The first redox process has also been ascribed to redox transitions of the aromatic rings surrounding the metal center [81]. It should be advertised the absence of redox processes related to CNT-f supports in FePc/CNT-f materials, probably because of interactions of these electroactive functionalities with Fe-containing species as the main driving force for stabilizing FePc molecules, which suppose a different chemical environment and are capable of inducing changes in the electrochemical behavior. Interestingly, it is noted that FeII/FeI and FeIII/FeII voltammetric peaks are more reversible and well-defined with both unmodified and modified hCNTs supports than with SWCNTs at the study conditions, indicating faster electron transfer owing to stronger interactions with FePc molecules. Moreover, phthalocyanines supported on SWCNTs normally have a certain bend that could reduce their aromaticity, thus affecting the redox response. Table 2 shows the FeIII/FeII cathodic peak potential for FePc/SWCNT, FePc/SWCNT-f, FePc/hCNT and FePc/hCNT-f, which can be used as a reactivity descriptor of FeN4 electrocatalysts for the ORR [21]. Comparing the two types of carbon nanotubes, responses for hCNT-related materials show more positive FeIII/FeII redox potential, which indicates higher activity, especially for such catalysts prepared from functionalized carbon supports. This effect could be related to the change from four-coordinated to penta-coordinated Fe with functionalities that implies an electron-withdrawing effect from the ligands and a favorable electronic redistribution [35]. Interestingly, this effect seems to be reinforced in FePc/hCNT-f than FePc/SWCNT-f due to the structure of hCNTs in the presence of highly reactive sites which could increase the interaction with N and P functional moieties, as well as with the FePc molecules, also according to previous characterization results. In addition, CVs in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH electrolyte (dashed lines in Fig. 3) were examined as a preliminary step for the catalytic study towards the ORR. An increase in current (in absolute value) is appreciated during the cathodic scanning related to the electroreduction of oxygen, which is the reaction under study, being more noticeable for FePc/hCNT and FePc/hCNT-f compared to FePc/SWCNT and FePc/SWCNT-f catalysts. 3.3 Study of the electrocatalytic activity and stability towards ORR To gain further insight into ORR performance of the as-prepared composites, as well as the commercial Pt/C (20 wt% Pt), the ORR was assessed by RRDE. Fig. 4 (a) displays the polarization curves j(E) acquired in 0.1 M KOH O2-saturated electrolyte at 1600 r/min and 5 mV s−1 from 1.0 V to 0.0 V. In addition, the number of electrons transferred (n) during the electrochemical reduction of O2 is shown in Fig. 4(b), which reflects the overall ORR mechanism for each catalytic complex. As detailed in Table 2, the ORR catalytic activity of the catalysts is drastically improved with the presence of FePc molecules. If both carbon supports are compared, the FePc composites with hCNTs seem to reveal better catalytic results than SWCNTs in terms of the onset potential (E ONSET) and, especially, the number of electrons transferred per oxygen molecule (n), comparable to the commercial Pt/C catalyst. It should be mentioned that, in this study, the E ONSET is established when the current density of the LSV curves reaches −0.1 mA cm−2 and the n is compared at 0.5 V. Interestingly, the slope of the LSV curve for FePc/hCNT-f catalyst in Fig. 4(a) is clearly higher to that for Pt/C catalyst, thereby suggesting a more optimal catalytic behaviour towards the ORR which are supported by the lower Tafel slope. Here, the higher limiting diffusion current density in the diffusion-controlled region observed for FePc/hCNT and FePc/hCNT-f in Fig. 4(a) could be related to the roughness of the electrode surface [82]. At this point and in line with the experimental evidence observed in Fig. 4, it can be suggested that the main active sites for O2 adsorption and electrochemical reduction in all FePc-containing catalysts are the central metal sites on FePc molecules. Therefore, Fig. 5 shows the proposed ORR redox mechanism under the studied conditions. Nonetheless, other active sites cannot be ruled out that could synergistically contribute to the ORR in these complex systems. On the other hand, the electrocatalytic behaviour of CNT and CNT-f samples could be mainly related to the presence of defects in the carbon material [54,83]. Here, despite the higher concentration of edge and defect sites in hCNTs they do not lead to an improvement in electrocatalytic behaviour compared to SWCNTs, but they produce a synergistic effect when FePc is supported. In this sense, the ORR in the presence of FePc/hCNT and FePc/hCNT-f catalysts principally follows the four-electron route with the generation of hydroxide anions (OH−) as the main product [30] (green pathway in Fig. 5) and a very low mol% of hydroperoxide anion (HO2 −) (5.4% and 2.8%, respectively), which are excellent results since the HO2 − is an undesirable product that adversely affects the stability of catalysts [84]. This means that the higher the activity and selectivity (lower HO2 − production), the higher the stability should be. In contrast, FePc/SWCNT and FePc/SWCNT-f show a number of electrons transferred close to 3.5 (mixed 4e− route in green with some contribution of 2e− transfer pathway in purple, Fig. 5), becoming less attractive because of their higher production of HO2 − during the electrocatalytic reaction compared with the other electrocatalyst. Here, it is also demonstrated that the presence of functionalities enhances both the EONSET and the selectivity of the ORR into OH− via a four-electron mechanism. This could be induced by the synergistic effect between FePc molecules attached by axial coordination with previously incorporated functionalities, together with the presence of highly reactive sites as edges, defects and functional moieties in the hCNTs. In addition, the more homogeneously the FePc molecules are distributed in the functionalized support, the higher the accessibility of the active center of iron towards the oxygen reduction. One important aspect that should be pointed out is that the active sites of these complexes in alkaline medium are initially occupied by the strong coordination with OH− anions from the electrolyte solution [21,35,86]. It has been revealed that MIII-OH is inactive due to the strongly adsorbed OH− and the reduced form MII corresponds to the active state in such complexes [21]. Therefore, the first step to start with the oxygen electrochemical reduction must be the release of the iron by replacing/transferring the OH− from the active sites in FePc molecules with adsorbed O2, following the mechanism proposed in Fig. 5 (step (1) and (2)). Here, a back-donation effect occurs between the O2 bonded and the orbitals of the metal center in FePc [87]. Tafel plots have been directly obtained from the LSV curves (Fig. 4c), in which the slopes at low overpotentials (kinetic control region) are also reported in Table 2. The Tafel slopes for all FePc-containing samples are close to 40 mV dec−1 in accordance with what is stated in the literature, in which the concentration of MII active sites is dependent on the potential [21,35]. In this case, it can be assumed that the oxygen adsorption/activation (step (2) in Fig. 5) is the rate-determining step [35,40,68]. It is remarkable that lower Tafel slope values are observed in SWCNT-f, hCNT-f, FePc/SWCNT-f and FePc/hCNT-f samples, compared with their corresponding unmodified samples. It strongly means that the formation of axial interactions between FePc and functionalities in modified supports facilitates the electron transfer during the ORR, even outperforming the commercial Pt/C catalyst. This is also evident in the bar graph in Fig. 4(d) with shows an improvement in the values of half-wave potentials (E 1/2) for the functionalized CNTs [77]. Therefore, very promising catalytic results towards the ORR are shown even with low amount of iron in the samples (∼1 wt%), where MN4 sites have been proven as the real active sites for the ORR. Interestingly, the choice of the optimal support has a considerable influence on the catalytic results. As it is known, one of the biggest downsides for practical applications of FePc is related to the decrease in long-term activity for the ORR [24]. The functionalization of carbon support is an interesting strategy to solve this problem due to the strong interactions with metal complexes, so a durability test has been carried out for the samples FePc/hCNT and FePc/hCNT-f in order to demonstrate it. The polarization curves at the 1st and 500th cycles are shown in Fig. 6 (a). After 500 cycles under operating conditions, FePc/hCNT-f presents remarkable stability, with a negative shift of 7 mV in the E 1/2, almost the same E ONSET and a decay of only 6.2% of the initial limiting current density. Nonetheless, a larger decay on FePc/hCNT is appreciated. The loss in the electrocatalytic activity can be directly associated with the production of HO2 − and the possible demetallation or “vanishing” of iron ion from FePc macrocycles [24], whose effect increases in the absence of axial coordination. According to XPS analysis in Fig. 2, where less contribution of free FePc molecules (what are related to no significant interaction with the support) appears in FePc/hCNT-f sample. Additionally, the stability of these electrocatalysts was assessed for 2 h by chronoamperometry test recorded at 0.65 V in 0.1 M KOH O2-saturated medium and a rotation rate of 1600 r/min (Fig. 6b). The profile of Pt/C catalyst has been presented for comparative purposes. For the practical use in direct methanol fuel cells, the methanol tolerance was also examined by adding 1 M CH3OH solution after 2 h and the data was further recorded for 1 h. The oxygen reduction current is maintained close to 85% with respect to the initial measurement for FePc/hCNT-f sample, whereas only 65% is retained for FePc/hCNT. Moreover, the selectivity of FePc/hCNT and FePc/hCNT-f catalysts is practically insensitive to the presence of 1.0 M CH3OH in the electrolyte, according to several studies in transition-metal N4 chelates [24], whereas Pt/C catalyst is affected by a total deactivation of the active sites towards the ORR. Table S1 shows the atomic surface composition obtained by XPS of FePc/hCNT and FePc/hCNT-f catalysts before and after 2 h of reaction by chronoamperometry test. Here, the Fe percentage for FePc/hCNT and FePc/hCNT-f catalysts after the stability test remain at 41% and 72%, respectively, compared to the initial value, which interestingly fits quite well the tendency of remaining oxygen reduction current in chronoamperometric curves in Fig. 6(b). In addition, Fe/P ratio before the test (0.2) indicates that only about 20% of P functionalities are expected to interact with all incorporated FePc molecules. However, N 1s XPS spectra in Fig. 4(b) also revealed that part of FePc molecules could not interact properly with the support according to the presence of -N-Fefree contribution. Therefore, the loss of Fe could be largely related to the release of free FePc molecules. Following this argument, despite the decrease in Fe content after the stability test, the ORR activity is not affected as much, which interestingly suggests that such catalytic activity is expected to come largely from the FePc molecules interacting with the support. In addition, the higher Fe/P ratio (0.4) after the test suggests that P species non-coordinate to FePc molecules are more easily oxidized and hydrolyzed under the conditions studied. Finally, the possible FePc agglomeration after ORR cannot be ruled out, which is expected to be more evident in FePc/hCNT than FePc/hCNT-f according to the higher interaction of FePc with functionalities. Interestingly, Fe 2p XPS spectra after the stability test in Fig. S11 (FePc/hCNTtest and FePc/hCNT-ftest, respectively) do not show very significant changes before and after the stability test, which suggests that the chemical environment of iron species is not significantly modified after 2 h of oxygen reduction. Under these results, FePc/hCNT-f proves to perform as a promising catalyst alternative to platinum-based catalysts at the cathode of numerous electrochemical devices. 3.4 Computational studies Computational calculations were conducted to reach a further understanding of the axial coordination of FePc with functionalities together with the role on such interaction in the ORR performance. Table S2 shows the DFT computed total energy data for all the optimized structures. Further details of the DFT calculation can be also found in Supplementary material. Fig. S12(a) shows the FePc cluster of the most stable equilibrium geometry with which the DFT calculations have been worked. The interaction of FePc molecules with functionalized carbon nanotubes results in covalent interaction of the central iron atom through phosphoryl oxygen (Fig. 7 c and d), as experimentally proposed, with an adsorption energy of −259.5 kJ mol−1. Here, a molecule of ortho- aminophenylphosphate acid has been grafted to the CNT in order to represent the functionalized carbon nanotubes in a simplified way, in the presence of phosphate and amine groups according to XPS analysis. Here, it is observed that the ortho- aminophenylphosphate acid molecule lies with the aromatic ring almost in parallel with the CNT due to the π-π interactions. This effect brings the FePc molecule closer to the nanotube (from 3.292 Å for FePc/CNT to 2.266 Å for FePc/CNT-f), allowing a more efficient electron transfer. Interestingly, the interaction in FePc/CNT-f seems to be more stable than that of FePc onto an unmodified CNT (−217.2 kJ mol−1) (Fig. 7a and b), which agrees with experimental results. A slight deformation of the planar graphitic structure of FePc molecule is appreciated in Fig. 7(b). Moreover, it is widely known that FePc molecules tend to aggregate with each other [20], so the simulation of two superimposed FePc has been carried out in the absence (Fig. S12b) and in the presence of the phosphonated species (Fig. S12c). The optimized structures demonstrated that such aggregation (interaction between two FePc molecules) is less stable when phosphate ligands axially interact with one FePc, with an adsorption energy of −248.2 kJ mol−1 (vs. −262.8 kJ mol−1 in the absence of axial coordination). In this sense, once phosphate groups interact with isolated FePc molecules, it is then less likely to be aggregated and therefore better distributed on the functionalized carbon surface, which is in full agreement with previous TEM and FESEM images (Fig. 1). These results lead to a better understanding of the outstanding catalytic performance and stability described in the previous section. Furthermore, the ORR mechanism has been estimated by studying the minimum energy pathway for the adsorption and dissociation of O2, either for FePc and FePc/2APPA systems in a continuous polarized aqueous solvent. As demonstrated by the simplified Pourbaix diagram obtained through computational calculations (Fig. S13), the active sites (central iron atoms) are initially coordinated by a hydroxide group in the range of potentials in which the ORR takes place and at a working pH of 13, as proposed in Fig. 5 and in other studies [21,35,86]. It is worth mentioning that the other side of the FePc and FePc/2APPA molecules must be sterically blocked as they are supported on CNTs. Nonetheless, phosphate ligands change to some extent the chemical stability of the species (Fig. S13b), thus affecting their chemical and catalytic properties as shown in the experimental section. In this sense, the stability range of FePc/2APPA-OH seems to be shifted towards more positive potentials, which could indicate a lower stabilization of the adsorbed OH− under the same working conditions, thus favoring the ORR performance. Therefore, once the active site is unblocked through the reduction of the OH species, the ORR takes place from the chemisorption of a dioxygen molecule, followed by multiple reduction steps and intermediates, through the four or two-electron catalytic cycle (green and purple route in Fig. 5, respectively). Fig. 8 displays the free energy diagrams of both FePc and FePc/2APPA systems for the ORR at different potentials, together with a comparison at the equilibrium thermodynamic potential (1.23 V). It can be seen that the reduction of the OH species and the regeneration of the active site is the step that requires higher energy, in agreement with reported works [77], especially with FePc (2.63 eV) than with FePc/2APPA (2.08 eV) at 1.23 V. In addition, the higher the applied overpotential, the more thermodynamically favorable is the ORR (E = 0.65 V and E = 0 V, orange and purple lines in Fig. 8(a and b), respectively). Interestingly, Fig. 8(c) shows that all the intermediates are less stabilized when FePc is axially coordinated with phosphate ligands, thus supporting the higher ORR efficiencies in this case. Dashed lines show the two-electron mechanism with the formation of HO2 −, which is energetically less favorable than the OH− generation via four-electron pathway (solid lines), as expected. In view of the results, a clear improvement of the ORR performance is seen for all FePc/CNT and FePc/CNT-f composites after a simple wet impregnation of FePc molecules on carbon-based supports. Nevertheless, better findings emerge for electrochemically functionalized carbon nanotubes support in terms of long-term stability of the active sites, E 1/2, electron transfer and selectivity towards the most energy-efficient four-electron process for the ORR in alkaline medium, which is induced by the synergistic effects between both components after the possible formation of axial interactions. This can favor the interaction between the central Fe atom and the O2 molecules, thus weakening the O-O bond and favorably destabilizing reaction intermediates through 4e− ORR pathway [88]. It might therefore be concluded that the close contact between metallic complexes and carbon-based supports is of key importance not only to improve the durability and electron transfer, but also to modulate the reactivity of the FePc for a more energy-efficient process. The optimal FePc/hCNT-f catalyst arises as a potential alternative candidate to the commercial Pt-based electrocatalysts, which outperforms many of non-heated FePc-based materials presented in previous reports [23,37,86,89–92] (Table S3) in terms of ease of preparation, low nominal metal content (low-cost) and excellent catalytic activity. 4 Conclusions In summary, this work has explored the electrochemical modification of nanostructured carbon material supports with functional moieties that can efficiently interact with FePc molecules as an interesting approach for the improvement of the ORR electrocatalytic activity and stability in alkaline medium. To that end, SWCNTs and hCNTs were previously modified in a highly controlled way by electrochemical methods in the presence of 2APPA monomers, thus introducing oligomeric materials on the carbon support which contain neutral amine/amide and phosphate species. Then, both the unmodified and functionalized CNTs were decorated with FePc molecules via a facile wet impregnation method. XPS and FTIR analysis validated the axial coordination between the central iron atom and phosphate ligands present in the carbon support, which leads to a more homogeneous dispersion of FePc macrocycles, as observed by TEM and FESEM images. Such strong interactions gave rise to molecular reorganization by breaking the symmetry of electronic density that favors the oxygen reduction by stabilizing the catalytic centers and lowering the stability of ORR intermediates. Moreover, the relevance of choosing the optimal support has been demonstrated, where hCNTs combined with FePc have shown the best catalytic results in this case, possibly due to the presence of highly reactive sites in the support (as edges, defects and functional moieties). Therefore, it is concluded that the enhancement of the catalytic performance is mainly related to the synergistic catalysis of modified carbon supports and metallic complexes through the axial coordination between FePc and phosphate groups. This approach offers a new scalable alternative for catalysts with better ORR performance and inspires for design of new FePc-based materials with high electrocatalytic activity, selectivity, good stability and methanol-tolerance, showing a competitive performance compared to the commercial platinum-based catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Iron(II) phthalocyanines (FePc) supported on functionalized nanostructured carbon materials have been studied as electrocatalysts for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) in an alkaline medium. Herein, two types of carbon nanotubes (CNTs) have been explored as support, Single-Walled Carbon Nanotubes and Herringbone Carbon Nanotubes (SWCNTs and hCNTs, respectively), both electrochemically modified with ortho- aminophenylphosphonic acid (2APPA), which provides phosphate axial coordinating ligands for the immobilization of FePc molecules. All the catalysts were prepared via a facile incipient wetness impregnation method. Comprehensive experimental analysis together with density functional theory (DFT) calculations has demonstrated both the importance of the five-coordinated Fe macrocycles that favor the interaction between the FePc and the carbon support, as well as the effect of the CNT structure in the ORR. FePc axial coordination provides a better dispersion, leading to higher stability and a favorable electron redistribution that also tunes the ORR performance by lowering the stability of the reaction intermediates. Interestingly, such improvement occurs with a very low content of metal (∼1 wt% Fe), which is especially remarkable when hCNT support is employed. This work provides a novel strategy for the development of Fe-containing complexes as precious metal-free catalysts towards the ORR.

coredata.dc:title: P-functionalized carbon nanotubes promote highly stable electrocatalysts based on Fe-phthalocyanines for oxygen reduction: Experimental and computational studies
